d16afa0ae7c.description: Mining the tech world for lively, meaningful tales. Part of WIRED Media Group.
d16afa0ae7c.name: Backchannel
d16afa0ae7c.shortDescription: Mining the tech world for lively, meaningful tales.

paragraphs.name: 60d7
paragraphs.text: And forget about infestations by critters like cockroaches. Nanobots will exterminate larger household pests en masse. The real terminators of the future wont wreck havoc on humanity: They’ll massacre our unwanted insect houseguests.

Humans have always done things that were considered normal at the time, that now seem horrific. People kept human beings as property. Doctors bled clients to release evil humors and treat medical conditions. Lobotomies were thought to cure mental illness. Urban dwellers flushed sewage and industrial pollution into their drinking water, then swam and fished in their own poop. Eventually it got so bad that our rivers were catching on fire. Violent and deadly wars were far more common.
paragraphs.name: 533c
ce9f
paragraphs.text: Nope, never had a womb, although perhaps tech will make that viable someday. I don’t think any man or woman alive today can predict the rate at which women will want to give birth naturally vs through an artificial womb. We won’t know until it’s an option. Right now, the US maternal death rate during childbirth is ~18/100,000; infant mortality is ~600/100000. The point is that artificial wombs will probably, eventually be easier and safer for both parent and baby. In that case, some will choose the natural method, but many will choose the safer method -especially women who might have high-risk pregnancies.
Technological Determinism, Just Say Know…
paragraphs.name: 53de

paragraphs.text: Please make it stop!
paragraphs.name: abf9

54b923871083.title: Are you sure that a male person can predict the will of a female to give birth, Because it’s…….

paragraphs.text:
Are you sure that a male person can predict the will of a female to give birth, Because it’s……. messy?
“ Creating a baby inside another human being is hazardous” — is it? is a success rate of 1 every 3 seconds that risky?
paragraphs.name: 8a05

paragraphs.text: I’m really hoping you had a womb at some point of your life other wise i don’t see what your point is.

cc158fdc861a.title: Can’t help thinking that dust mites and or other organisms train the young immune system to…

paragraphs.text: Can’t help thinking that dust mites and or other organisms train the young immune system to tolerate external insults, and that stronger allergic reactions happen if this training fails. So dirt and dust mites aren’t necessarily ‘bad’. The problem of waste disposal is not usually just the ‘how’ but also the ‘how much?’. When we start stacking…
paragraphs.name: fecc

a6e137ee4e4.title: I understand your concerns and that bleak scenario is indeed a possibility.

paragraphs.text: I understand your concerns and that bleak scenario is indeed a possibility. I am much more optimistic about the ability of mankind to overcome its challenges and shortcomings. I am a firm believer that we can innovate our way out of any problem, so long as the will is there.

paragraphs.text: Hi Matt, thought provoking post! I’d like to take the opposite view and mention that our descendants may envy us also! For example, because of our lesser technology — my job is in tech, but I sometimes remember wistfully a time where everyone around me didn’t have a smartphone in their hands all of the time. I love seeing people reading actual books…

paragraphs.text: We are swimming in our own poop every day in this modern era too. Except it’s economico-politico-cultural poop. And we lerned to be casual about swallowing from time to time..

paragraphs.text: Great to read this. I may be a dystopian pessimist that expects a future probably closer to “Mad Max”, simply because Homo sapiens is such an inexhaustible source of disappointment for me — but I still love to surround myself with optimists and mostly the work of optimists. So kudos to this great article.

96a9dfe79954.title: You do realize how far off we are technologically and biologically to achieve something like this?

paragraphs.text: You do realize how far off we are technologically and biologically to achieve something like this? The woman’s body changes as it creates and supports the fetus, including her brain, preparing her to be able to feed and develop her infant post-birth. And many women don’t consider pregnancy to be messy nor an inconvenience

140978f91f6c.title: You’re notes on fossil fuels are spot on, but I think it goes deeper than that—our recklessness for…

paragraphs.text: You’re notes on fossil fuels are spot on, but I think it goes deeper than that—our recklessness for the environment overall is pretty devastating in the long-run. Overfishing (which you touch on), deforestation, even a general disregard for biodiversity… I think even now we can look back 50–100 years and shake our heads. I can’t imagine what the perspective in the distant future would be.
paragraphs.name: bf53

e0f16b271a71.title: 1) Universal basic income – or societal dividends.

paragraphs.text: 1) Universal basic income – or societal dividends. Our current leading economic system – free markets / capitalism – were designed in a time before we could fundamentally and measure collective contributions. For an age of resource scarcity, where society needed to somehow select winners and losers. In the future, there will be a societal dividend…

919beac887cc.title: I think they will skoff at centuries of wars over which religion was the correct one.

e13e36393b4d.title: All of this assumes that technological civilization with liberal values will survive.

paragraphs.text: All of this assumes that technological civilization with liberal values will survive. Unfortunately, that is not a sure thing.

f059aa48f9e7.title: Agreed! The mass extinction we’re precipitating may be the biggest disaster of all.

paragraphs.text: Agreed! The mass extinction we’re precipitating may be the biggest disaster of all. Genetic diversity may turn out to be our most valuable commodity in the future and our ancestors may mourn all the species we’re driven to extinction.
paragraphs.name: aed7

d71b4ebcdde.title: The analytical “scientist” of the 19th century saw human rights as a crime against the cool…

paragraphs.text: The analytical “scientist” of the 19th century saw human rights as a crime against the cool calculating natural darwinistic blade of evolution. The bureaucrats of ancient times saw poverty and slavery as a necessary social linchpin in terms of wealth distribution and labor.

paragraphs.text: Great points! Tech is going to do some interesting things to our definition of what it means to be ‘human’ and some people aren’t going to like enhancements. I do beleive in the future that ‘naturists’ who shun tech will become a lifestyle choice. I just wonder how viable that lifestyle will be in a modern economy.
